author: Charles Campbell
title: Poll: Trump’s Favorability Rating Tumbles As He Prepares To Take Office
text:
House Passes Resolution That Sets Up Repeal Of Obamacare 
Gallup contended that Trump’s low transition approval is not simply reflective of his popular vote loss, noting that George W. Bush, who also lost the popular vote, enjoyed a 61 percent approval rating in mid-January 2001. 
Trump has also lost non-partisan support, as his approval among independents has fallen from 46 percent to 33 percent over the past month. 
Despite the incoming president’s transition disapproval rating, the poll found that more than half of respondents rated Trump’s cabinet choices as “average” while 44 percent said the cabinet picks are “below average” or “poor.”   
“Whatever the reasons, Trump’s approach since Nov. 8 has not softened Americans’ concerns about him, as a slight majority now disapprove of how he is handling the presidential transition,” Gallup stated. 
“Trump’s inauguration speech on Jan. 20 presents a major opportunity for the soon-to-be 45 th president to alter how Americans view him,” the company added. “But after that, his image will depend more on how his actions affect real-world outcomes including the economy, healthcare costs, taxes and national security.” 
After earning a surprise victory on Election Day, Trump enjoyed a boost in overall approval. But those ratings have fallen. 
According to a Nov. 22 Quinnipiac University poll, the president-elect enjoyed a 56 percent approval rating in regards to leadership skills. But in a Jan. 10 Quinnipiac poll, Trump’s approval rating had fallen to 49 percent.
